titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Dinanda Nooney At Home in Brooklyn photographs V1990.020
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Weatherly Stephan
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2011-11-28T15:56-0500

did.unittitle: Dinanda Nooney At Home in Brooklyn photographs

physdesc.extent: in two manuscript boxes and one oversize box.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Dinanda Nooney At Home in Brooklyn photographs date from 1976 to 1985 (bulk dates: 1978 to 1979) and contain 223 items. Photographs in the collection depict Brooklyn residents from a variety of age, ethnic, and economic groups in and near their homes. The collection is composed of interior and exterior views of apartments and houses, park scenes, street scenes, and photographs of residents engaged in social and family events. Rooftop views are also included, showing the Gowanus and Sunset Park neighborhoods of Brooklyn. Neighborhoods photographed in the collection include Fort Greene, Greenpoint, Bedford-Stuyvesant, Clinton Hill, Crown Heights, Flatbush, Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, Boerum Hill, Sheepshead Bay, Carroll Gardens, Windsor Terrace, Cobble Hill, Park Slope, Prospect Heights, Prospect Park South, Sea Gate, Brooklyn Heights, Bay Ridge, Gowanus, and Sunset Park. Each photograph is identified by date, name of subject, street address, and neighborhood.
A copy of the At Home in Brooklyn exhibition catalog, dated 1985, is included with the collection.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Dinanda H. Nooney (1918-2004) was a documentary photographer and native New Yorker. Nooney's first extensive photographic project documented the collapsed West Side Highway in Manhattan in the mid 1970s. Nooney began photographing families throughout the borough of Brooklyn in 1976. Covering dozens of neighborhoods in the borough from Greenpoint to Sea Gate, Nooney documented over 150 families, completing the bulk of the work between 1978 and 1979. Photographs from the Brooklyn project were exhibited at the Long Island Historical Society in 1985, under the title At Home in Brooklyn.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: Based on the life span of the creator, all items in this collection will enter the public domain by 2074. For information on securing rights to publish or reproduce, please see the Brooklyn Historical Society Reproduction Rights Policy.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids note
otherfindaid.p: Item-level description and digital versions of images from the collection are available for searching via the image database in the library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Fully processed to the item level.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Dinanda Nooney At Home in Brooklyn photographs, V1990.020, Box number, Object ID number; Brooklyn Historical Society.
